title: Launch YouTube in Brazil
prompt: YouTube wants to launch in Brazil. There are 10M potential creators but almost zero local content. Advertisers won't pay without scale. Creators won't join without an audience. You're the PM. You have 90 days.
problemDefinition: Classic two-sided marketplace cold start: creators need viewers, viewers need content, advertisers need both
Competitive pressure: TikTok, Instagram Reels, and Kwai are already recruiting Brazilian creators
Cultural complexity: Brazil has intense passion in specific categories (funk, futebol, novela culture) â€” a generic launch will fail

questions.text: What's your first move as PM?

options.label: Deep discovery research
options.text: Run discovery interviews with Brazilian creators, viewers, and advertisers. Map the opportunity space before committing to anything.

options.label: Find the sharpest wedge
options.text: Identify the one content category where Brazil already has passionate fans but no local supply â€” and nail that first.

options.label: Ship an MVP this month
options.text: Get something live fast. 90 days of real data beats 90 days of planning. Hire 10 seed creators and ship.

options.label: Map the growth loop first
options.text: Model the creator-viewer flywheel. Identify where supply or demand breaks first, then design an experiment to de-risk it.

questions.text: YouTube Brazil has 10M potential creators but no local content yet. What do you prioritize?

options.label: Validate creator willingness first
options.text: Before investing in supply, prove creators will actually show up. Run assumption tests with 100 potential creators.

options.label: Partner with top 100 creators
options.text: Identify Brazil's top micro-influencers and offer white-glove onboarding, early monetization access, and dedicated support.

options.label: Launch with music creators only
options.text: Music is Brazil's cultural heartbeat. Start with a single category that already has demand and concentrate all resources there.

options.label: Build creator referral engine
options.text: Launch a creator-refers-creator program. Give existing creators incentives to recruit peers â€” let the supply side grow itself.

questions.text: Your VP asks for a launch date. What do you say?

options.label: "After we've de-risked the 4 key assumptions"
options.text: Set a date only after running discovery sprints on creator supply, viewer demand, advertiser appetite, and content moderation.

options.label: "6 weeks â€” here's the wedge we'll nail first"
options.text: Commit to a date, but scope it to the music creator wedge. Not a full launch â€” a sharp bet with clear success criteria.

options.label: "2 weeks â€” we'll learn more from being live"
options.text: Ship in 2 weeks with whatever we have. We'll get 100x better signal from real users than from any research sprint.

options.label: "When we hit 1000 activated creators"
options.text: Don't give a date â€” give a milestone. We launch when we have creator supply. Map the work backward from that.

theSplit.question: Should YouTube ship in Brazil before validating the creator supply?

sides.reasoning: Market moves fast. 90 days of live data beats 90 days of research. Ship, learn, iterate.
Shipping without creator supply validation is how you destroy a brand in a new market.
Wrong question. Don't ship 'YouTube Brazil' â€” ship the sharpest wedge that de-risks the flywheel.

cagan.name: Marty Cagan
cagan.summary: Prove the creator flywheel works before you scale
cagan.spicyQuote: If you launch in Brazil without proving creators will stay, you haven't launched â€” you've created an expensive ghost town.
breakdown: The core risk is supply-side, not demand-side â€” viewers will come if content exists
Value risk: Will creators produce content worth watching? Unknown.
Feasibility risk: Can YouTube's recommendation engine work with <1% local content?
Business viability: Advertisers need brand-safe, local-language content to spend
solution: Run a 6-week continuous discovery sprint with 50 potential Brazilian creators
Test creator willingness with a lightweight 'Creator Early Access' landing page
Define explicit go/no-go criteria before any engineering investment
Only launch when you can defend the four risks to the board
cagan.disagreement: The Execution AI Monster's 'ship in 2 weeks' approach is how you enter a market with a dud and spend 2 years cleaning up the brand damage. Lenny's growth loop model assumes you have supply to run experiments on â€” you don't. Doshi's wedge strategy is closer, but skips the discovery work that tells you *which* wedge is real.
mvp: 'Creator Early Access' waitlist with 1,000 Brazilian sign-ups
Structured discovery interviews with 50 potential creators
Assumption testing: will they post weekly for 90 days?
Go/no-go scorecard shared with exec before any $1 of engineering
metrics: Creator interview completion rate (target: 50 within 3 weeks)
Assumption validation score across 4 risk categories
Creator stated intent to post weekly (proxy for supply viability)
Advertiser brand-safety assessment: go or no-go
roadmap: Weeks 1-2: Discovery â€” Creator interviews, assumption mapping, risk scorecard
Weeks 3-4: Validate â€” Test creator intent with lightweight landing page + follow-ups
Weeks 5-6: Go/No-Go â€” Exec review, resource commitment, clear success definition
Weeks 7-12: Seed Launch â€” 100 curated creators, full support, strict quality bar

torres.name: Teresa Torres
torres.summary: Map the opportunity tree before committing to any solution
torres.spicyQuote: Every week we're not talking to Brazilian creators is a week we're building on assumptions. I don't care about your launch date â€” I care about your evidence threshold.
breakdown: The opportunity space isn't 'launch YouTube Brazil' â€” it's 'enable Brazilian creator income'
Current solutions: TikTok, Instagram Reels, local platforms â€” creators have options
Key assumption gap: We don't know what's actually blocking creator supply
The Opportunity Solution Tree needs branches before you can pick a leaf
solution: Weekly touchpoints with 5-7 Brazilian creators â€” not a one-time research sprint
Map the full Opportunity Solution Tree: creator blockers, viewer needs, advertiser constraints
Run assumption tests weekly: fast, cheap, specific to one branch of the OST
Identify the sub-problem where evidence is strongest before writing a line of code
torres.disagreement: Cagan's 6-week discovery sprint is a step in the right direction, but it's still too waterfall â€” one big research phase followed by a decision. Discovery should be continuous. The Execution AI Monster's approach is the opposite of what the evidence supports: you can't iterate your way out of a fundamental supply problem. Doshi's strategic clarity is admirable but he's solving the wrong problem if we haven't validated the opportunity.
mvp: Ongoing weekly interviews with 5-7 potential Brazilian creators
OST diagram with assumptions mapped per branch
Assumption tests: Creator income viability, audience discovery mechanism
One solved sub-problem with evidence before any broad launch
metrics: Weekly creator interview cadence (are we learning, or just talking?)
Assumption invalidation rate (how fast are we killing bad ideas?)
Opportunity branches validated vs. total in OST
Evidence confidence score per solution direction
roadmap: Week 1+: Weekly Cadence â€” Establish creator interview rhythm â€” this never stops
Weeks 2-4: OST Build â€” Map opportunities, rank by evidence potential, set assumption tests
Weeks 5-8: Test Branches â€” Run cheap assumption tests on top 3 OST branches
Week 9+: Evidence-led Build â€” Build only what the OST + evidence supports

doshi.name: Shreyas Doshi
doshi.summary: Pick the sharpest wedge, concentrate all resources, measure ruthlessly
doshi.spicyQuote: Everyone is asking 'when do we launch.' That's a Level 2 question. The Level 1 question is: what is the one thing that, if true, makes the entire flywheel spin?
breakdown: This is a two-sided market cold-start â€” the hardest class of product problem
Anti-goal: Do NOT launch a 'general' YouTube Brazil â€” that's the recipe for a thin, unmemorable product
The strategic insight: Brazil has intense passion in specific categories (funk, futebol, novela culture)
LNO analysis: The Leverage move is picking the right wedge. Everything else is Overhead.
solution: Pre-mortem: List the 5 ways this fails. 'No local content' and 'wrong wedge' top the list.
Identify the one content category where Brazil has outsized passion and zero good supply
Concentrate all resources â€” creator support, monetization access, editorial â€” on that one wedge
Define crisp success criteria: 500 activated creators, 2M local views, before expanding
doshi.disagreement: Cagan and Torres are right to want validation, but they risk analysis paralysis â€” 6 weeks of interviews can give you 6 more weeks of uncertainty. The Execution AI Monster's shipping speed is admirable but strategically reckless: you'll ship the wrong thing fast. Lenny's growth loop thinking is good but skips the upstream question of which wedge to run the loop on.
mvp: Wedge selection framework: score 5 categories on passion, supply gap, monetization speed
Secure 50 music/funk creators with exclusive early access + monetization Day 1
Define the 'activated creator' bar before launch (posts 4x/week, 10K+ views)
Ship music-only YouTube Brazil with a clear 90-day success scorecard
metrics: Wedge category: creator supply within 30 days (target: 500)
Week-4 creator retention rate (are they sticking?)
Local content per category per day (supply health metric)
90-day go/expand decision: hit criteria or pivot wedge
roadmap: Week 1: Wedge Selection â€” Score categories, pick music/funk, pre-mortem the bet
Weeks 2-4: Creator Seeding â€” 50 curated creators, full white-glove support, monetization access
Weeks 5-8: Activate & Measure â€” Track activated creator rate, adjust creator support model
Weeks 9-12: Wedge Expansion â€” If 500 activated creators: expand to adjacent category

lenny.name: Lenny Rachitsky
lenny.summary: Personally recruit the first 100 creators, then build the referral flywheel
lenny.spicyQuote: The best cold-start playbook always has one pattern: the founding team personally recruits the first 100 supply-side users. Airbnb photographed apartments. Uber drove cars. YouTube Brazil needs to personally activate the first 100 creators.
breakdown: This is a marketplace cold-start problem â€” solved dozens of times, but only one way works
The creator-viewer loop only spins when local content density hits a critical threshold
Historical benchmark: ~500 active local creators before the algorithmic flywheel takes over
The fastest path: high-touch creator recruitment + referral program + viewer feedback loop
solution: Personal recruitment: team members directly recruit the first 100 Brazilian creators
Creator referral program: give activated creators incentives to recruit 2 peers each
Weekly experiment cadence: test creator retention interventions and pick winners
Track the 'creator D30 retention' metric obsessively â€” if it's <50%, nothing else matters
lenny.disagreement: Torres's continuous discovery cadence is great but moves too slow for a market window. Brazil's creator economy is growing now â€” Kwai, TikTok, and Instagram are all recruiting. Cagan's risk framework is right on the theory, but he'd still be interviewing creators while TikTok locks them up. The Execution AI Monster's 'ship it' approach is close, but misses the creator retention flywheel â€” you can't acquisition-out your way to creator stickiness.
mvp: Direct personal outreach to 200 Brazilian creators by YouTube team members
Creator referral program: $500 bonus per recruited creator who activates
Weekly experiment: test 3 creator-retention interventions, cut losers
Creator dashboard: show earnings trajectory and comparative benchmark
metrics: Creator D30 retention (north star: >50% posting weekly at day 30)
Creator referral rate (target: each activated creator recruits 1.5 peers)
Time to first video posted (target: <72 hours from signup)
Local content density by category (trigger for algorithmic promotion)
roadmap: Weeks 1-2: Manual Hustle â€” Team personally recruits 100 creators â€” no shortcuts
Weeks 3-5: Referral Engine â€” Launch creator referral, test incentive structures weekly
Weeks 6-9: Retention Loop â€” Experiment on D7 and D30 creator retention interventions
Weeks 10-12: Flywheel Check â€” Hit 500 active creators â†’ algorithmic promotion kicks in

exec.name: Execution AI Monster
exec.role: Ship now. Fix later. Win markets.
exec.summary: Ship in 2 weeks, learn from real data, iterate from a position of being live
exec.spicyQuote: You have 90 days. TikTok Brazil has been running for 2 years. The market isn't waiting for your discovery sprint. Ship in 2 weeks. Iterate from a position of being live rather than being right.
breakdown: The biggest risk isn't a bad launch â€” it's showing up late to a market TikTok already owns
Brazil is a high-context, social-first culture: content spreads fast when it hits
Two weeks to get something live: seed 20 creators, basic monetization, Brazilian recommendations
Every week offline is a week TikTok reinforces its habits with Brazilian creators
solution: Hire 5 contractor creator scouts in Brazil this week â€” start recruiting immediately
Set a 14-day live deadline: whatever is ready ships, everything else iterates post-launch
Give creators a 6-month revenue guarantee: remove the economic risk of early adoption
Ship, measure, iterate â€” don't let perfect be the enemy of live
exec.disagreement: Cagan and Torres would still be running discovery interviews in Week 6 while TikTok signs exclusive creator deals. Their four-risk framework assumes you have time â€” you don't. Doshi's wedge strategy adds a planning layer that delays shipping by 2-3 weeks. Lenny's personal outreach is right, but the timelines are too slow. In fast-moving markets, being live with a 60-out-of-100 product beats being in beta with a 90-out-of-100 product.
mvp: Launch in 14 days: 20 seed creators, Brazilian UI localization, basic recommendations
6-month revenue guarantee for first 100 creators (removes supply-side risk)
Live data dashboard: track creator activity and viewer retention from Day 1
Weekly iteration sprint: one improvement cycle per week, shipped on Fridays
metrics: Days to first Brazilian creator video (target: <14 from project kick-off)
Creator activation in Week 1 (target: 20 posting weekly)
Week-2 viewer retention (are people watching Brazilian content?)
Competitive heat map: are we signing creators before TikTok does?
roadmap: Days 1-7: Sprint Setup â€” Hire scouts, recruit 20 creators, localize UI â€” ship in 14 days
Days 8-14: Launch Day â€” Go live. Broken things are fine. Offline is not.
Weeks 3-6: Fast Iteration â€” Weekly ship cycles. Fix what breaks. Double what works.
Weeks 7-12: Scale â€” Revenue guarantee program, 500 creators, algorithmic growth

mvpOptions.name: Creator Early Access Program
mvpOptions.reason: Validate supply-side willingness before any engineering investment. Cheapest way to test if creators will actually show up.

mvpOptions.name: Music Creator Wedge Launch
mvpOptions.reason: Concentrate all resources on Brazil's strongest content category. Sharp scope, clear success criteria, manageable risk.

mvpOptions.name: Personal Recruitment + Referral Engine
mvpOptions.reason: Hand-recruit the first 100, then let the referral flywheel scale supply. Proven cold-start pattern from Airbnb, Uber.

mvpOptions.name: 14-Day Blitz Launch
mvpOptions.reason: Ship whatever is ready in 2 weeks. Revenue-guarantee creators. Learn from live data instead of hypotheticals.

premortem: Creator churn: We recruit 500 creators but 80% stop posting after Week 2 because monetization is too slow â€” we built supply that evaporated
Wrong wedge: We bet on music creators but the real opportunity was futebol commentary â€” 3 months wasted on the wrong category
Competitive lockout: TikTok signs exclusive deals with Brazil's top 50 creators while we're still in discovery â€” we lose the supply war before launching
vitalQuestion: If you could only know one thing before committing to the launch plan â€” creator willingness to post weekly, viewer demand for local content, advertiser willingness to pay, or competitive timeline pressure â€” which would it be, and why?

cagan_torres.name: The Evidence Purist
cagan_torres.tagline: You won't ship until the data says yes

cagan_doshi.name: The Strategic Guardian
cagan_doshi.tagline: You de-risk with frameworks, not gut feel

cagan_lenny.name: The Measured Builder
cagan_lenny.tagline: You build for growth but validate first

torres_doshi.name: The Structured Thinker
torres_doshi.tagline: You map the problem before you solve it

torres_lenny.name: The Discovery Optimizer
torres_lenny.tagline: You find opportunities then measure what works

doshi_lenny.name: The Strategic Experimenter
doshi_lenny.tagline: You pick the right wedge then run the loop

doshi_exec.name: The Fast Strategist
doshi_exec.tagline: You think sharp then move fast

lenny_exec.name: The Growth Hacker
lenny_exec.tagline: You ship loops and measure everything

cagan_exec.name: The Paradox PM
cagan_exec.tagline: You want to validate AND ship yesterday

torres_exec.name: The Rapid Discoverer
torres_exec.tagline: You discover fast by building real things
